content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun concept mixing guitar with arithmetic. Statement is clear with the C chord example showing exactly how the calculation works. Nice variety in test cases from single notes to full 22 chord progressions.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and fast. As a guitarist, I had to try it. :)

Just a quick note about what you call the “first string”:
In music, the first string is the thinnest (high E) and the sixth string is the thickest (low E).
To avoid any confusion among musicians, I would explicitly state in the objective: “The strings are numbered from 1 to 6 in the order in which they appear in the input” (or something equivalent). 

Good work!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I probably took more than 5 minutes, but I tried to do it in shortest for some reasons. Good, though if I was you, I'd use common chords as tests, like X-3-2-0-1-0 from your example as Test 2 (not than I'm an expert at guitare it may be one I don't know of)

Hello! That's a really nice idea you got there, a fun math problem wearing a cool guitar costume.
I think that the example is very helpful, but it carries a lot of the explanation, and the overall text is a bit long compared to the amount of rules that need to be understood (could also be a strenght considering it makes the problem really easy to understand).
I also noticed that some of the informations are only suggested by the example (the order of the strings particularly).
Also, maybe you wanted people to find it by themselves (in that case it is totally fine), but the numbering rule could be expressed in a more compact way like with a formula.
Thanks!
In the Input section, please change "Next [[N]] lines" to "Next [[chordsCount]] lines". Thank you.

General
* The concept is straightforward, though the explanation can become a bit lengthy. The suggestions below largely follow what you've written. You may want to omit or simplify some of the points so that the statement can be shorter.

Goal
* The statement relies too much on the example to convey the rules, instead of defining the rules explicitly first and then illustrating them with an example. Please consider replacing the second paragraph with the following text:

On a standard guitar, there are 6 strings, floating over a fretboard of 21 frets. Each string can be played either open (no finger) or with a finger placed on a fret. Each such position corresponds to a unique number.

The numbering of the fretboard is defined as follows:
- The open string of the 1st string is numbered {{1}}.
- Each fret increases the number by {{1}}.
- Each string has {{21}} possible notes (open string + 20 frets).
- Numbering continues string by string.
- The 21st fret of the 6th string is numbered {{132}}.

Several notes played together make a chord.

A chord is written as 6 values separated by hyphens, one per string:
- A number between {{1}} and {{20}} means the string is played on that fret.
- {{0}} means the string is played open.
- {{X}} means the string is not played and should be ignored.

* After the above change, modify the example accordingly:

  • Change "An X means the note is not played" to "indicated by the {{X}}".

  • Delete "called".

  • Show the number for each string, and the answer to the example.

* Replace the final paragraph with:

Your task is to translate the played notes of the given chords and output the sum.

* Players might get confused by the different numbering conventions (for example, the open string is represented by 0 in the input but treated as note number 1 when calculating the output). You might want to add a short tip at the end to alert them.

Input
* Consider deleting "Any number means the note is played. Any X represents strings that are not played, thus should be ignored." for simplification.

Output
* Please add "played" before "note".

Constraints
* Please delete the second constraint.

* Please add the following:

Each [[chord]] contains exactly 6 notes.

Fret values are between {{0}} and {{20}}.

Cases
* Please add one or more cases to include fret values not yet covered in the existing cases.

Thanks.

Hi there! Thanks a lot for your feedback, that's actually much clearer.
I've updated everything, let me know if that's ok with you!

Hey! Thanks a lot for your feedback!

For the rules implied by the example, and to simply some things, do you think it would be better to have it displayed like this?

Fret values per string:
-------------------------------
(string 6)  [111|112| ... |132]
(string 5)  [89|90|91| ... |110]
(string 4)  [67|68|69| ... |88]
(string 3)  [45|46|47| ... |66]
(string 2)  [23|24|25| ... |44]
(string 1)  [1|2|3|4 | ... |22]

Thanks a lot!
And regarding your remark about the chord used in test 2, you're absolutely right. This is not a chord. In fact I guess I wanted to do 0-2-2-0-0-0 instead, but I didn't notice my mistake -_- Thank you, that would make more sense indeed! I'll update that right now.

Thanks for the approval :) 

Yeah that was a shortcut for a pure "tech" point of view, but you're right it could be confusing! I'll correct that
I think that clarifies a lot! Maybe you can also mention explicitly that the first number in the input represents string 1.

Here is the revamped text ([...] is replacing text that has not changed). Tell me what you think :)

<<

[...]

(string 6)  [111|112| ... |132]
(string 5)  [89|90|91| ... |110]
(string 4)  [67|68|69| ... |88]
(string 3)  [45|46|47| ... |66]
(string 2)  [23|24|25| ... |44]
(string 1)  [1|2|3|4 | ... |22]

[...]

A chord is written as 6 values separated by hyphens, one per string:
- Each value corresponds to a string, from the 1st to the 6th.
[...]

Here is an example for the chord C: X-3-2-0-1-0
According to the rules above, the values behind are: 
- X on 1st string: {{no value}}
- 3 on 2nd string: {{26}}
- 2 on 3rd string: {{47}}
- 0 on 4th string: {{67}}
- 1 on 5th string: {{90}}
- 0 on 6th string: {{111}}
The {{output}} will then be the sum of all these values: {{341}}

[...]

>>
Thank you! It's much clearer now.
